misconceptions.name: Implemented a different problem (distance between points) instead of grade-to-letter calculator
misconceptions.description: The student wrote a program to compute the distance between two points rather than reading a single numeric grade (0-100) and printing a corresponding letter grade using conditionals.
misconceptions.student_belief: I can solve this question by writing a program that reads two points' coordinates and prints the distance between them.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: This task requires reading one numeric grade value (0-100) and using conditional logic to map that number to a letter grade (A, B, C, D, or F), then printing the letter grade.
symptoms: Program prompts for x1, y1, x2, y2 instead of a single grade
No variables or logic related to grades or letter grades
No conditional statements (if/else) to handle grade ranges
Output describes distance between two points, not a letter grade
misconceptions.root_cause: Likely misreading the assignment or reusing code from a different exercise about point distances.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the problem statement and start from scratch: declare a variable for the numeric grade, read one value with Scanner, and use if/else-if/else to check which range it falls into (90–100, 80–89, etc.) and print the corresponding letter.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The class name, prompts, variables, computations, and output all clearly correspond to a distance-between-points problem and contain nothing related to grades or letters.

evidence.note: Entire program is about computing distance between two points; there is no reading of a single grade, no conditional ranges, and no letter grade output.

misconceptions.name: Complete Misinterpretation of Task Requirements (Distance Calculation Submitted for Grade Calculator)
misconceptions.description: The student implemented a program to calculate the distance between two Cartesian points, which is a solution for a different problem, entirely failing to implement the required Grade Calculator functionality using conditionals and grade ranges.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to have submitted code intended for a different assignment (possibly a geometry or math problem) instead of the requested grade calculation program. They assumed the task required reading coordinates and applying the distance formula.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The task required reading a single integer 'grade' and using conditional logic (if/else if/else) to compare it against predefined numeric ranges (e.g., 90-100, 80-89) to output a corresponding letter grade.
symptoms: Code reads four double inputs (x1, y1, x2, y2) instead of one integer/double grade.
Code calculates the distance formula (using Math.sqrt and squaring differences).
Output message relates to distance, not a letter grade.
No conditional logic (if/else) for grade calculation is present.
misconceptions.root_cause: Submission error, likely submitting the wrong file or fundamentally misunderstanding the current assignment prompt.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Review the assignment prompt carefully. The task is to calculate a letter grade (A, B, C, D, F) based on a numeric score using if/else statements, not to calculate geometric distance.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code explicitly implements the distance formula and outputs a distance value, directly contradicting every requirement of the 'Grade Calculator' problem.

evidence.note: The code reads four coordinates instead of a single numeric grade.
The core logic is the distance formula, not grade evaluation.

evidence.snippet: System.out.println("The distance of the two points is " + d);
evidence.note: The output is the calculated distance, not a letter grade.

misconceptions.name: Completely wrong problem solved
misconceptions.description: The student appears to have submitted code for a different problem entirely (distance between two points) instead of the grade calculator problem specified in Q3.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student believes this submission addresses the grade calculator requirement, or has submitted the wrong file.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The student should submit a program that reads a single numeric grade (0-100) and outputs the corresponding letter grade (A/B/C/D/F) based on the specified ranges.
symptoms: Code reads x1, y1, x2, y2 coordinates instead of a grade
Code calculates Euclidean distance instead of converting grade to letter
Output shows distance formula result instead of letter grade
Class name is 'Q3DistanceBetweenPoints' not 'Q3GradeCalculator' or similar
misconceptions.root_cause: Student submitted code for the wrong problem, possibly copy-pasted from a previous assignment or mixed up file submissions.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Start over with the correct problem: (1) Read one integer grade value, (2) Use if-else statements to check ranges 90-100, 80-89, 70-79, 60-69, and below 60, (3) Output the corresponding letter grade.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Absolute certainty - the submitted code solves a completely different problem (distance calculation) with no overlap to the grade calculator requirements.

evidence.note: This entire program calculates the Euclidean distance between two points, not the letter grade conversion specified in Q3.
Input prompts ask for coordinates, not a numeric grade as required by Q3.

misconceptions.task: Correct Boolean ranges for A and B
misconceptions.name: Implemented distance formula instead of grade range checks
misconceptions.description: The student wrote a program to compute the distance between two points rather than checking numeric grade ranges and mapping them to letter grades. There are no conditional statements to distinguish between A, B, C, D, and F ranges.
misconceptions.student_belief: For this question, I should write a program that calculates the distance between two points using the distance formula.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program should read a single numeric grade (0–100) and use conditional statements (if/else-if/else) to test whether the grade falls in the A, B, C, D, or F ranges and then output the appropriate letter.
symptoms: Class is named Q3DistanceBetweenPoints, not something related to grades
Variables represent coordinates (x1, y1, x2, y2) and distance d instead of a grade
Uses Math.sqrt and arithmetic for distance rather than any Boolean logic or conditions
No if, else-if, or else statements present in the program
misconceptions.root_cause: Likely confusion about the assignment prompt or mixing up problems, leading to implementing the wrong algorithm entirely.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Discard the distance-formula logic and rewrite main to read a single numeric grade, then use an if/else-if/else ladder to check 90–100, 80–89, 70–79, 60–69, and below 60, printing the corresponding letter.
related_concepts: Mapping numeric values to categorical outputs
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The entire program structure and all variable names and computations are devoted to distance between points with no mention of grades or letter outputs.

evidence.note: The entire logic is about distance between points; there are no grade variables or conditional checks for A/B ranges as required.

misconceptions.name: Reads coordinate pairs instead of a single grade value
misconceptions.description: Instead of reading one numeric grade from the user, the program prompts for and reads four double values representing two points (x1, y1, x2, y2).
misconceptions.student_belief: The program should prompt for two points, each with x and y coordinates, and read four numbers from the keyboard.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program should prompt the user once (e.g., "Enter grade: ") and read a single numeric grade value representing a percentage between 0 and 100.
symptoms: Prompt text asks for x1 and y1, then x2 and y2, not a grade
Uses nextDouble four times instead of once
No variable indicating a grade or score is read
misconceptions.root_cause: Misinterpretation of the input requirements for the problem, possibly reusing code from a different task.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Replace the prompts with a single "Enter grade: " message and read exactly one numeric value (e.g., int grade = in.nextInt();). Remove all coordinate-related inputs.
related_concepts: Mapping problem description to input variables
Choosing appropriate variable names for problem context
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The prompts and four successive nextDouble calls clearly indicate the student is gathering coordinates rather than a single grade.

evidence.note: Shows the student reading four coordinate values instead of a single numeric grade as specified.

misconceptions.task: Mapping each range to correct letter output
misconceptions.name: Does not output any letter grade
misconceptions.description: The program prints a numeric distance with descriptive text instead of printing a letter grade (A, B, C, D, or F) based on the numeric input.
misconceptions.student_belief: The output should display the distance between two points in a sentence like "The distance of the two points is ...".
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The output should be of the form "Letter grade: X" where X is the correct letter (A, B, C, D, or F) corresponding to the numeric grade provided by the user.
symptoms: Output message refers to distance, not grades
Prints a numeric result instead of a single letter character
No code constructs a string like "Letter grade: B"
misconceptions.root_cause: Using an output format from a different problem and not adapting it to the grade calculator specification.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Change the final print statement to output the computed letter grade, e.g., System.out.println("Letter grade: " + letter); where letter is a char or String determined by the grade ranges.
related_concepts: Designing user-facing output to match specification
Using variables to represent categorical results
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The only printed line is a distance sentence; there is no mention or variable for letter grades.

evidence.note: Final output prints a distance value, not a letter grade string as required.

misconceptions.name: Incorrect Program Implementation
misconceptions.description: The student implemented a solution for calculating the distance between two points instead of the required Grade Calculator program. Consequently, the program does not fulfill any of the requirements related to reading a grade or applying grading logic.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to have submitted code for a different assignment (Distance Between Points) or misunderstood the requirement entirely.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program must read a single numeric grade (0-100) and use conditional logic (if/else if/else) to determine and print the corresponding letter grade (A, B, C, D, F).
symptoms: Program calculates distance, not grade
Reads four double inputs (x1, y1, x2, y2) instead of one integer/double grade input
Lacks any conditional logic (if/else) for grading
misconceptions.root_cause: Major submission error or misunderstanding of the assignment instructions.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Please review the assignment prompt for Q3 and ensure the submitted code addresses the Grade Calculator problem.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: High confidence as the code explicitly calculates distance using Math.sqrt and reads four coordinates, matching no description of a Grade Calculator.

evidence.note: The class name itself indicates the wrong problem.
Input is four coordinates for distance calculation, not a single numeric grade.
The code implements the distance formula (square root of sum of squared differences) and outputs the distance, confirming the wrong problem was solved.
